Much is being said about the impact that starlink satellites are having on astronomy and astrophotography. Currently, the fact that about 12,000 satellites are put into orbit is viewed with suspicion, filling the skies with more space junk. On the other hand Spacex keeps arguing that the albedo of their satellites is quite low and that once they occupy their orbits, they will be quite difficult to observe, just in the mornings or in the evenings... I for my part see that even though in space there are already several thousand satellites in orbit, the skies are still relatively clean of that kind of pollution, I think Spacex is aware of the impact of their project and they are taking it quite seriously. But what if Spacex could pay its debt to the astronomical community in a very original way? Imagine if each of those starlink satellites were equipped with a pair of small optical telescopes and a small radio telescope, one of the optical ones to take images of the earth, the other to take images of the firmament and the radio telescope to "see" in the radio spectrum...could each of these telescopes be put to the service of the scientific community...these telescopes in spite of being small and very similar to those that anyone could buy for their personal use, already put in space, would give much better results than on earth...and if they could be used together to perform interferometry?...imagine the level of resolution that would be had if they could be put to work together, it would be like a planetary scale telescope...it's just an idea...as an added value to the simple fact of providing the internet service...

Clarification on Hayabusa2's Small Carry-On Impactor: The copper projectile packed with explosives was what's called an Explosively Formed Penetrator. The explosives were used to propel a solid copper slug to a high-velocity impact. (Fast enough to blast a new 10-meter crater in the asteroid!) It's not like Hayabusa2 dropped a bomb on the asteroid, which then exploded.

Hi Tim! I admire your detailed discussion of each topic that you touch on in your videos! This is really cool!

I offer you a topic for a new analysis: make a video about the mass excellence (the ratio of the mass of the empty rocket to the mass of the filled (in Russian: мassovoe sovershenstvo\массовое совершенство)) of a rocket and a spaceship. There is little simple information on this subject; everything must be read in the special literature. And the parameter is very important. For example, if the ship’s mass was near-zero (of course, it’s impossible, but imagine (or simulate in the KSP)), then when there is very little fuel left in the tanks, the thrust to mass ratio will increase and the main supply of delta-V will be at the lowest supply fuel. That is, a decrease in the dry mass of a spacecraft directly increases its energy supply, although this is not obvious, because when the rocket is completely filled with fuel, the dry mass seems insignificant.

That is why Musk constantly talks about the mass excellence (the ratio of the mass of the empty rocket to the mass of the filled) of new ships (in general, I heard this phrase from him for the first time). To popularize space, I think this video will be very useful, especially if there is animation and demonstration (I just cheatfully reduced the mass of some details in the KSP to check what this leads to. The effect is not noticeable in the beginning, but it has a huge effect when the fuel on outcome). And I know, this is all described by Tsiolkovsky. But I didn’t read it until I wondered ...

Somewhere I saw criticism of the Merlin engines, saying that it makes no difference how much the engines weigh, if compared to the mass of a full rocket, this is half a percent. And such articles are misleading. When the rocket is almost empty, the weight of all components is of great importance, including and the weight of the engines, especially if there are a lot of engines on board.

The reason why people are so mad about Boeing calling the Starliner mission a "success" is because all they've had is off-nominal performances.


During the abort test, it failed to deploy all its parachutes, and then ruptured a fuel tank when it hit the ground. Imagine if both tanks ruptured - hypergolics do not need a flame to ignite. That's 2 failures already: chute deployment, and fuel containment.


On the launch, it oriented wrong because of the mission cock and wasted a bunch of fuel. True, if astronauts were aboard, they could have manually overridden, but the fact is that they never should have had-to. That's a third failure mode.


The docking was never tested. If NASA authorizes them to fly humans without autonomously docking with ISS, they'd be doing it irresponsibly. They should have to PROVE it works in-reality before getting the greenlight to fly people.


Add to that, SpaceX has done more pad tests, and will even do an in-flight abort, and that the 1 catastrophic failure was on the capsule that had already been flown, docked and was fished out of the ocean.


The internet is mad because SpaceX deserves to be the first to ISS with human passengers. Boeing/ULA doesn't get grounded when they fail, but SpaceX does. Boeing does not have to live up to the same quality standards that SpaceX has to live up to. Boeing is less innovative and forward-thinking, and they aren't as open to the public as SpaceX. And Boeing is far more expensive than SpaceX, yet still seem to win all kinds of contracts. Boeing is part of the military industrial complex, and the revolving door, and they get sweetheart deals because of crony capitalism. Meanwhile SpaceX represents real capitalism: working hard, becoming the best, and yet they aren't rewarded (to the same degree) as Boeing.


I think everybody is glad that Boeing is in the race, but people aren't glad about the blatant favoritism they get from NASA and the US government.

Starhopper is a vastly different rocket from grasshopper. It is built quite differently, has some very different nuances in terms of flight characteristics and is a much bigger albeit slightly shorter rocket with potentially far greater payload.

Achievements like taking picture of black hole may soon become impossible to do because of Starlink and other similar satellite constellations. I know, EHT telescope works with radio waves, but there is a next generation of extremely capable optical and infrared ground based telescope that are expected to become operational in next few years: LSST, GMT, ELT. Who knows what discoveries awaits us with those telescopes which could be jeopardized by mega satellite constellations. Also, there is a community of amateur astronomers that work on gathering data (tracking comets, asteroids, variable stars, planets) or science outreach and probably are having same impact as having access to Youtube. For them (us), bright satellite constellations are great annoyance. Amateur astronomers wont be able to buy and operate space telescope for themselves.

Hey Tim, just wanted to let you know something.

In Germany, there's an annual stream event called "Friendly Fire". It's a charity stream going on for 12 hours, and features many popular German YouTubers and Streamers. It takes place in early December, and I happen to know that the manager and planner for this event has to start planning everything in *February*! Just as a heads-up on how much work it actually is to set up a live stream event with multiple live guests.
So although I really dig the idea of creating an actual award show, for 2020, especially since it's the first year, I'd advise you to start off with a semi-live stream having you and your crew prepare live moderation, but with mostly pre-recorded, non-live interviews, maybe even just recorded over Skype if an actual meetup is impossible to arrange. It's much easier to have you and a your crew visiting them with the setup, than bringing 10 people to the studio, and have flights, accommodations and catering work for 2 days and studio space and tech equipment all working in a critical moment for an hour straight.
I do believe in your hard work, but live shows are harsh. Streams can lag. Microphones fail. Flights get delayed or cancelled. I really want the awards to become a thing, and it'd be a shame for its reputation to become "that thing where tech team tried to fix a sound issue for 25 minutes and 3 out of 5 award winners couldn't show up and comment on winning the award because life happens." So do yourself a favor and plan a show, but do the critical stuff that does involve other people beforehand so you have a second and third shot if something goes wrong.

All the best, I love your channel. In fact, I've been recommending it to any person that is maybe just slightly interested in spaceflight (and to many who I suppose aren't even into spaceflight, or maybe weren't but now are thanks to your content). Good luck in 2020.

Hello, Comp Sci guy here. The issue wasn't necessarily that there was a bug, but that it was a bug that resulted from a phenomenally idiotic design decision. And it was a bug that was caused by trusting a piece of data without verifying it which any computer programmer will tell you is not a smart thing to do. From what I have gathered, there were a number of other variables that could have told the capsule's guidance program that the time it had was off, but the program only trusted the MET it pulled to execute regimes based on a table instead of checking the conditions to see if it was indeed time for those flight regimes.

At 24:30 it did not "take until 2019 to explore the other half of the moon". During the Apollo missions while Michael Collins was flying orbits around the moon his CSM (command service module) had cameras in its belly taking very high res (70 mil. film photos) of the Lunar surface during each revolution. Then during Apollo's 12 and 14, 15, 16 and finally 17 each CSM had more and more sophisticated cameras onboard the propulsive body of the CSM that serviced the command module.
For sure, during the return phase beginning during Apollo 11 and during the return flight home had to make an EVA (extra vehicular activity) otherwise known as a "spacewalk" , the astronauts had to leave the capsule and retrieve the very high definition canisters of film that was shot from cameras built into the CSMs. There cameras had extremely "hi-def" film for their time. In fact the 70mm film used back in those days is equivalent to the film used in the very large "IMax" film cameras for the studios which first used IMAX film over 15 years ago.

In conclusion, the "far side of the Moon" was first visualized by NASA Apollo Lunar CSM space vehicles which carried extremely hi-res 70 mm film.
Just ask yourselves. Why did Buzz Aldrin need to make a special trip on the return flight home from the Moon during Apollo 11 in order to retrieve film canisters from the belly of the CSM only to bring them onboard the "Command Capsule" and back to Earth? Very few people are aware that Buzz had to make a very important EVA in order to retrieve those 70mm hi-def film canisters of the "Backside" of the Moon.

I think what made Starhopper so big was that it showed that SpaceX was actually serious about this whole Starship thing. We've gotten so used to pretty much every US president giving a Mars speech etc. only for NASA to not get the funding it would need to do it, that seeing physical progress being made felt like a new and very significant thing. What makes SpaceX, in general, so exciting is that they're shaking up the status quo. I think Starhopper was the point when a lot of the public first thought that they might actually get to see people on Mars in their lifetime. It was putting action and funding into something that's been all talk and no action up until that point. In other words, it wasn't the feat itself that was so inspiring, it was the fact that the feat meant things are changing in a way that they haven't since the space race. It's inspiring because they said they were going to do this, they put the money into it, and then actually started on the path. That's something that in terms of pushing human space flight forward, hasn't ever happened in my lifetime before.

Tim, I understand that you are trying to moderate the debate around the Starliner flight and yes, the debate should be civilized and constructive. But there is something that you need to address instead of dismissing it with "Space is hard!".

The trouble with the Starliner failure is that it points to underlying systemic problems within the Boeing. First, there was the failure to properly attach a parachute during the abort test and then there was the Starliner clock error. Both of these are unforced, quality control issues, that just shouldn't happen. For a company that spends billions of dollars of taxpayer money, this is very troubling. This was supposed to be a full rehearsal for the eventual human flight and the QC should have been as strict as if there were astronauts on board. What if something even more serious slips during the manned flight?

Yes, the SpaceX Dragon exploded - on a surface a much more serious problem. But this was a complex, engineering problem - something the tests are indeed for and can be rationally solved. Also, it happened during a situation that is on its own extremely unlikely - a launch abort. Both Boeing failures happened during procedures which will be a part of every flight - something that is scary as hell and Boeing should be held responsible for it. Saying that everything else went well is a poor argument - during the last flight of Columbia everything before the re-entry went well too.
The argument that space is hard just doesn't cut it here either, because the failures are human-related, not space-related and you should address that.
